item.title: ËøàÂÖãÂ∞î¬∑ÊãâÂ∏ïÊ≥¢ÁâπÔºà Michael Rapaport ÔºâÂú®Áß∞Â∏ÇÈïø‚ÄúÁôΩÁó¥‰Ωê‰º¶‚Äù Ôºà Zoron the Moron Ôºâ‰πãÂêéÁúãÂà∞2029Âπ¥
item.description:
Michael Rapaport¬†is setting his sights on a new career path.

The 55-year-old actor announced on the Monday, Jan. 5 episode of his¬†‚ÄúI Am Rapaport‚Äù podcast¬†that he plans on running for mayor of New York City in 2029, stating, ‚ÄúMy name is Michael Rapaport, a.k.a. Mayor Rapaport. Mr. Mayor Rapaport.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet me tell you something, guys, girls, women, children of all ages. 2025 was crazy, and I don‚Äôt see it getting any‚Ä¶ calmer or cooler in 2026, the way things started,‚Äù he continued. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why I‚Äôm running for mayor.‚Äù

His announcement comes after Zohran Mamdani was sworn in as the city‚Äôs new mayor earlier this month. Rapaport has been very vocal about his dislike for Mamdani, who is known for his democratic socialist policies.

Rapaport is most well-known for his on-screen work as an actor, but aims to follow in the footsteps of fellow actors turned politicians, Arnold Schwarzenegger and¬†Ronald Reagan, by becoming the next mayor of New York City.

Here is Rapaport‚Äôs journey from actor to mayoral candidate.

Stand-up comedian

Rapaport made a name for himself as a stand-up comedian before transitioning into an actor.

As a comedian, Rapaport was known for his unfiltered and often aggressive, rant-driven style of humor, which often included his opinions on everyday topics.

‚ÄúI definitely remember the first time I performed on stage,‚Äù he said on ‚ÄúThe Jose Candelario Show‚Äù in February 2025. ‚ÄúI was 19. It was in an open mic in the afternoon‚Ä¶ but I did the open mic in Manhattan somewhere downtown, and I don‚Äôt remember what jokes I did, but I remember my goal was if I could get one person to laugh, I was going to do it again.‚Äù

He explained that his stand-up career ‚Äúgot me into acting, which I fell in love with.‚Äù After his acting career took off, he quit stand-up at 25 years old, and only recently started getting back into it.

‚ÄòZebrahead‚Äô

Rapaport‚Äôs first major role was in the 1992 movie ‚ÄúZebrahead,‚Äù in which he played a young Jewish boy who falls in love with a black teenage girl in Detroit.

The movie tackles the difficulty of being in an interracial relationship at the time. It was a success among critics and earned a modest $1.5 million at the box office.

While the movie was not a major blockbuster success, Rapaport‚Äôs performance was well received and led to further leading roles in movies.

‚ÄòTrue Romance‚Äô

Following his first on-screen role, the actor was cast in his breakout role in the 1993 film, ‚ÄúTrue Romance.‚Äù

Also starring Christian Slater,¬†Brad Pitt, Patricia Arquette and many other big names, the movie follows a comic-book enthusiast, Clarence, and a prostitute, Alabama, who fall in love. A series of events lead to Clarence killing Alabama‚Äôs pimp and accidentally stealing a suitcase of cocaine.

The two then work toward selling it, but soon find themselves on the radar of the mob. Rapaport plays Dick Ritchie, a friend of Clarence‚Äôs, who helps him deal with the mob.

‚ÄúThat was the only movie that I‚Äôve ever done that I knew was going to be a good movie,‚Äù Rapaport said in a September 2016¬†episode of his podcast. ‚ÄúWhen you make a movie it‚Äôs like if you‚Äôre baking a cake. All the ingredients were there. The recipe was there, and you had a fantastic chef.‚Äù

TV appearances

He continued to prove he had a strong acting ability by appearing in many big movies, including ‚ÄúHigher Learning,‚Äù ‚ÄúMetro‚Äù and ‚ÄúCop Land,‚Äù before also setting his sights on television.

Rapaport gained mainstream TV recognition when he landed a recurring role on the hit sitcom, ‚ÄúFriends,‚Äù playing Detective Gary, the boyfriend of Lisa Kudrow‚Äôs character, Phoebe.

The actor later starred in the hit shows ‚ÄúBoston Public,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe War at Home.‚Äù He also starred in ‚ÄúPrison Break,‚Äù playing the main antagonist in the fourth season.

He continued with guest spots on many TV shows, while also appearing in films. Most recently he starred in the Netflix show, ‚ÄúAtypical.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúI loved the character and I loved the show, and just the response that people have had to it has been really overwhelming to be honest with you,‚Äù Rapaport told the¬†‚ÄúDan Patrick Show‚Äù¬†in November 2019. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a family show, and I‚Äôm very proud of ‚ÄòAtypical.'‚Äù

He also appeared in a few episodes of ‚ÄúOnly Murders in the Building.‚Äù

‚ÄòI Am Rapaport: Stereo Podcast‚Äô

Rapaport launched his podcast, ‚ÄúI Am Rapaport: Stereo Podcast,‚Äù in 2014, which went on to gain more mainstream success the following year.

At the time, it focused on New York sports teams and NBA commentary, leading him to win best sports podcast at the Podcast Awards in 2015. It was at this point that he started having audiences call in and doing live shows.

As the podcast continued to gain popularity, clips of the episodes began going viral on social media, and Rapaport began inviting celebrity guests, including actors, NBA players and comedians. This helped expose the actor to a younger audience.

More recently, the podcast has become more of a space for Rapaport to comment on politics and social issues. He briefly signed with Barstool Sports in 2017, before being let go in 2018.

Arrest

Following his breakthrough performances in film and television, Rapaport experiences some tough times in his personal life.

In May 1997, the actor was arrested after he showed up at his ex-girlfriend, actress Lili Taylor‚Äôs house at 1 a.m. and was banging on her window repeatedly. He later pleaded guilty to aggravated harassment, and according to¬†E! News, told the judge that he also called Taylor 21 times in a four-day period after their breakup.

As a result, the judge issued a protection order keeping Rapaport away from Taylor, and also mandated the actor get counseling twice a month for a year. Had he violated any of these conditions, he would be sentenced to one year of jail time.

Marriage

Rapaport first found love in 2000, when he married television producer and writer Nichole Beattie.

The two were married for seven years and welcomed two sons together, Julian and Maceo, before getting divorced in 2007.

Following his divorce from Beattie, Rapaport reconnected with his former girlfriend, Kebe Dunn, who he first dated in the ‚Äô90s. It is unclear when exactly they rekindled their romance, but they were first spotted out together in 2012.

They eventually tied the knot in 2016, and are often posting about one another on social media. ‚ÄúEverything is better with you. Happy Anniversary @michaelrapaport you bring me joyüñ§,‚Äù she wrote on Instagram to celebrate their third anniversary in December 2019.

Mayoral race

Following¬†the election of Mamdani¬†as mayor, Rapaport announced he is planning on running for the office in the 2029 election cycle.

In addition to making the announcement on his podcast, Rapaport also took to¬†Instagram¬†to share the news, emphasizing in the video that he was ‚Äúborn and raised in New York City.‚Äù

‚ÄúBorn. Raised. NYC. Nothing‚Äôs free. No bulls‚Äî. No fake grins,‚Äù he wrote in the caption. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll own my mistakes, apologize when I screw up, and fight to make this city safe, affordable, and thriving. You got Zoron the Moron now‚Ä¶Mayor Rapaport is coming. How you like them apples? üçéüóΩ.‚Äù

Many people in the comments section were supportive of the actor‚Äôs decision, including Jackie Goldschneider, who wrote: ‚ÄúI will lead the efforts from NJ!! üôåüôå,‚Äù and Dorit Kemsley, who left clapping hands emojis.

‚ÄúI will move to NYC just to vote for you! ‚úàÔ∏è,‚Äù one fan wrote. Another added, ‚ÄúLove the sound of it ‚Äì Mayor Rappaport! How can I help!?‚Äù
item.author: Fox News

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õÂ≠¶Ê†°ÈõÜ‰ºöÁØÆÁêÉÊïôÁªÉÁöÑ2Â≤ÅÂ•≥ÂÑøÊÇ£ÊúâÁΩïËßÅÁñæÁóÖÔºå ‚ÄúÊîªÂáª‚ÄùÂô®ÂÆò
item.description:
A Long Island community rallied to support a basketball coach‚Äôs 2-year-old daughter as she battles a devastating slew of medical issues ‚Äî including a terrifying and incredibly rare genetic mutation.

‚ÄúShe was born with chronic illness in one kidney, and over the last eight months, it‚Äôs gone to both kidneys, and then six months ago, she was diagnosed with the gene mutation,‚Äù Hewlett High School assistant boys varsity coach Jonathon Welsh told The Post of his daughter, Rowyn Grace.

Rowyn Grace has an altered COL4A1 gene, which Welsh said makes ‚Äúher body miss the glue that holds it together.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe mutation makes her blood vessels and tissues dangerously fragile‚Ä¶it attacks all her organs, and it‚Äôs a systemic threat that puts her at constant risk for internal bleeding and organ failure.

‚ÄúIt has fewer than 1,000 diagnosed cases worldwide,‚Äù added Welsh, who said doctors are still determining if there is a connection to the little girl‚Äôs kidney problems.

The 39-year-old father of two girls is an eligible kidney donor and would give his to his daughter in a heartbeat if needed, he said.

No quit in this family

These nightmares can‚Äôt dampen the spirit of Rowyn Grace, however, as Welsh called her a very vocal and hilarious 2-year-old who is always looking on the bright side of things.

She‚Äôs often found at Hewlett with a clipboard and whistle, helping her dad run practice.

‚ÄúThis is a time where we can just, in quotes, be living a normal life. Coaching is a passion of mine,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThe community understood that this is an outlet for my family and me.‚Äù

Seeing the pain they were in, head coach and close friend Andrew DeBernardo sought to act on behalf of the Welsh family at the start of the school year.

He proposed a tournament in honor of Rowyn Grace, but her dad wanted to keep the struggles private.

‚ÄúI said no initially, and then he brought it up again, and I said no. And then he said, ‚ÄòReally think about it,‚Äù Welsh recalled.

‚ÄúHe was super passionate about it, because that time was when we were starting to really learn the ins and outs of what was going on with her.‚Äù

Welsh ultimately welcomed the idea, as the school teamed up with the ‚Äúlifeline‚Äù Michael Magro Foundation to put together Saturday‚Äôs Rowyn Grace Classic and fundraiser at Hewlett.

The all-day action featured the Bulldogs‚Äô girls JV and varsity playing Jericho, and the boys teams taking on Long Beach, as players warmed up in ‚ÄúRowyn Strong‚Äù shirts also seen in the packed stands.

‚ÄúThe atmosphere was electric for all four games,‚Äù Welsh said of the ‚Äúchampionship‚Äù caliber vibes.

He spoke ahead of the varsity boys game, and Welsh‚Äôs family, many of whom flew in from out of town, were expecting the emotional dad to get choked up before getting out the first sentence.

‚ÄúI got through all of it until the last two lines, and I kind of had to gather myself again,‚Äù Welsh said.

‚ÄúIt was easier than I expected, because of the support that came out from the community‚Ä¶especially seeing all the alumni on the sidelines and baseline.‚Äù

Rowyn Grace ‚Äúwas very shy at first,‚Äù but her dad said that changed once the PA announcer cued her in.

‚ÄúMyself, our boys basketball team lined up at our bench and made a tunnel, and then we introduced Rowyn, and she ran through,‚Äù Welsh said.

‚ÄúShe was having a really good time with that,‚Äù he added of the raucous applause from the capacity crowd.

Soon after, she and her 4-year-old big sister Rhyan took their usual spots behind the bench ‚Äî pom poms in hand ‚Äî as the Bulldogs brought home a 77-59 win.

Welsh, who is also the school‚Äôs head softball manager, is orchestrating a tournament at Farmingdale State College‚Äôs field in April to continue the movement.

It‚Äôs not only for his No. 1 fan, but also for others going through similar hardship.

‚ÄúA few people that I‚Äôve known in high school or that I ran across in college that didn‚Äôt know our story, that are going through something similar, that have reached out this morning,‚Äù Welsh said Sunday.

‚ÄúSo the fact that it‚Äôs now connecting dots to multiple people across New York right now is something that words can‚Äôt even explain‚Ä¶It was the biggest win that our family could have ever had.‚Äù
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: Ëá™Áî±Ê¥æÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊîøÂÆ¢ËÆ°ÂàíÁªôËá™Â∑±Âä†Ëñ™16% Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰ªñ‰ª¨ËøòÊ≤°ÊúâÊîæÂºÉ
item.description:
The new City Council speaker squashed a plan by lefty council members to give themselves a big fat pay raise ‚Äî but the pols aren‚Äôt giving up their dreams of bigger salaries just yet, The Post has learned.¬†

Newly minted Speaker Julie Menin was adamant about stopping the politicians behind a bill pushing to fatten council paychecks 16% on the taxpayer dime, sources said.

‚ÄúThe body has never done their own pay raise, so that wasn‚Äôt a path she was comfortable with‚Äù a source close to Menin said. ¬†

‚ÄúShe wants to make sure they‚Äôre doing it in a way that is accountable and transparent,‚Äù the source added, noting the push to vote on the current legislation was coming mostly from the progressive caucus.¬†

But they may not be the end of the politicians seeking to give themselves more spending cash.

A compromise from the raise-hungry liberals may be to push new Mayor Zohran Mamdani to form a commission that will be told to fast track considering raises.

Traditionally, the council has introduced legislation calling on the mayor to form a Quadrennial commission consisting of three appointees ‚Äì which would then give a recommendation on salary increases and dollar amounts.¬†

Since the first commission to recommend pay raises for elected officials was formed in 1987 ‚Äî the council has had five pay raises ‚Äî most recently in 2016.

The current bill, intro 1493 sponsored by Council member Nantasha Williams, has sought to boost members‚Äô salaries from $148,500 to $172,500. But after Menin knocked down the effort, Williams said she‚Äôll amend the bill so the council cannot directly vote on increasing themselves.

‚ÄúThe City Council bill is not axed,‚Äù Williams told The Post.¬†

‚ÄúOn the contrary, I have been in active conversations with Speaker Menin about a better alternative new bill that we are introducing that will mandate the commission to expeditiously focus on the pay raise,‚Äù she explained.

Multiple sources confirmed the new legislation would be introduced to the council imminently and that Menin has spoken directly to the mayor about the new plan.

A co-sponsor of the bill, Council member Sean Abreu, echoed Williams‚Äô change of tune.¬†

‚ÄúThe good government way of establishing salaries for elected officials would be through a commission,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the most fair way of doing it.‚Äù
item.author: Hannah Fierick

item.title: ÂâçÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∑ûÂ∑ûÈïøÂÆâÂæ∑È≤Å¬∑ÁßëËé´Ôºà Andrew Cuomo ÔºâÂú®Â∏ÇÈïøËæìÁªôÈ©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÂêéÔºåÂ∞ÜÂú®Á∫¶Áø∞¬∑Âç°ÈΩêÈ©¨ËíÇËø™ÊñØÔºà John Catsimatidis ÔºâÁöÑÁîµÂè∞‰∏ªÊåÅÊØèÂë®ÂπøÊí≠ËäÇÁõÆ
item.description:
Former Gov. Andrew Cuomo may be making a comeback after losing the 2024 mayoral election to democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not what you think.

The 68-year-old Democrat is in talks with 77 WABC to host a weekly radio gig, the station‚Äôs owner John Catsimatidis, confirmed to The Post.

‚ÄúI think he wants to do [a show] once a week. He wants to stay in touch with the people,‚Äù said Catsimatidis, who said a show is ‚Äúin the works.‚Äù

The station owner, who also owns the Gristedes supermarket chain in the city, teased the possible gig on his ‚ÄúCats Roundtable‚Äù program Sunday in an interview with the former governor.

‚ÄúI hear you may be talking a little bit more on WABC radio in the near future,‚Äù Catsimatidis said.

‚ÄúI think your station has an audience that is participatory, and large,‚Äù Cuomo replied. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very important ‚Ä¶ that we understand what‚Äôs going on and have informed dialogue and your station is a great vehicle to do that.‚Äù

Cuomo spokesman Richard Azzopardi said the longtime politician will be a publicly engaged citizen.

‚ÄúFrom fighting the scourge of antisemitism to the future of cities and urban America, among other issues, Andrew Cuomo has a perspective and points of view that more than 900,000 New Yorkers supported in the last race,‚Äù Azzopardi said. ‚ÄúHe will continue to speak out on the important issues on WABC and many other media outlets.‚Äù

Catsimatidis declined to say if Cuomo would be paid, though the ex-governor doesn‚Äôt need a radio gig for the money.

He made $4.7 million in 2024 via his legal consulting business.

After resigning as governor in 2021, Cuomo briefly hosted his own podcast.

The possibility of Cuomo hopping on WABC‚Äôs airwaves comes after his Republican rival in last year‚Äôs election left his show on the station amid an election row with its the station owner.

Curtis Sliwa, founder of beret-wearing vigilante group the Guardian Angels, switched to iHeartMedia‚Äôs 710 WOR when Catsimatidis and hosts on the station said the Republican should step aside to give Cuomo a better shot at beating Mamdani

Cuomo was running on an independent line, while Mamdani held the Democratic Party line after beating the ex-governor and a handful of other candidates in a ranked-choice primary.

Sliwa refused and took exception to the lack of support. Mamdani went on to win and was sworn in as mayor this month.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈ¶ñÂ∏≠Êï¥ÂΩ¢Â§ñÁßëÂåªÁîüÁöÑÊÇ£ËÄÖÂÖ•‰æµ‰∫ÜÁΩë‰∏äÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑË£∏‰ΩìÂõæÂÉè‚ÄîÂåªÁîü‚ÄúÂøΩÁï•‰∫ÜÂØªÊ±ÇÂ∏ÆÂä©ÁöÑËØ∑Ê±Ç‚Äù ÔºöË•øË£Ö
item.description:
Dozens of patients of a premier Manhattan plastic surgeon had their hacked nude images and social security numbers posted online ‚Äî and the doctor failed to notify both his clients and the authorities, according to a class action lawsuit.

Dr. Richard Swift‚Äôs office, located on the monied Upper East Side, was hacked in an alleged malware attack last year, with a Russian-hosted website featuring sensitive information of at least 22 patients, the suit claims.¬†

Linda Qutawna was one of the clients, alleging that images of her breasts as part of a consultation were hacked and published online ‚Äî and she only found out when the hackers reached out to her directly.¬†

Qutawna, who first contacted Swift‚Äôs office in 2023 to remove breast implants, told The Post that the experience has been ‚Äútraumatizing‚Äù and ‚Äúhumiliating.‚Äù¬†

‚ÄúHe just didn‚Äôt want to take any accountability or acknowledge it, or even reassure us‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs the bare minimum that we were looking for,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut he didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

The lawsuit blames Swift‚Äôs ‚Äúinadequately protected computer systems‚Äù for the hack and alleges that the surgeon ‚Äúfailed to adhere to his statutory duty to alert his patients that his firm suffered from a data breach.‚Äù

The doc also ‚Äúignored repeated requests for information from [Qutawna],‚Äù court papers claim.

In addition, attorney Daniel S. Szalkiewicz alleged that Swift never informed Attorney General Letitia James‚Äô office about the data breach, as required by law.

James‚Äô office confirmed to The Post on Thursday that Swift has not reported any data breach.

Qutawna claims in the suit that she was told to send nude images of her ‚Äúexposed breasts‚Äù to the office via email.

She then scheduled a surgery to remove the implants, but later canceled it prior to moving out of state.

In July 2025, an email arrived in Qutawna‚Äôs inbox with the subject line: ‚ÄúYour photos from Richard Swift MD have been published,‚Äù according to the suit.¬†

The message contained three nude images she emailed the office two years earlier, and a link to a now-offline website.

That site also contained patient names, social security numbers, medical and financial information ‚Äî and naked images of patients, including of their breasts and genitalia, Qutawna claims.

‚ÄúI was terrified and overwhelmed,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbecause once those images and your identifying information are out there, you don‚Äôt know who has them or how they‚Äôll be used.‚Äù

At first, the site had 16 patient files, but soon it grew to 22 individuals, according to the suit.

Lawyers for Swift insisted in a filing that ‚ÄúLinda Qutawna has never had a doctor-patient relationship, or any other form of relationship, with Dr. Swift.‚Äù

And because Swift never made a promise to notify her of any data breach, it was not ‚Äúactionable deception‚Äù when she was left in the dark, attorney Justin Kelton said in the court papers.

When contacted by The Post, Swift‚Äôs office declined to comment ‚Äî and promptly hung up.

However, another plastic surgeon told The Post that Swift‚Äôs claim is ‚Äútotal bulls‚Äìt.‚Äù

‚ÄúA consultation establishes the doctor-patient relationship.‚Äù

Kelton did not respond to The Post‚Äôs repeated requests for comment.¬†

Qutawna said she contacted Swift‚Äôs office twice to ask about a possible breach and what actions they were taking, but received no response.

Three other victims Qutawna spoke with said they had also not received any information about the breach, the suit alleges.

Szalkiewicz said Swift ‚Äúcaused immense harm‚Äù by not alerting patients.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs worse is that the doctor then ignored pleas for help,‚Äù the attorney said.

The site wasn‚Äôt taken down until mid-September, Qutawna claimed.

‚ÄúWe think that he was basically just gonna kick the can down the road for as long as he could, and just pretend it never happened,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúWhen a doctor mishandles your most intimate information, it undermines the one place where you‚Äôre required to be vulnerable and trust that you‚Äôre going to be protected.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Êä§Â£´Â∑•‰ºöÂ®ÅËÉÅÂú®Êà™Ê≠¢Êó•ÊúüÂâçÁΩ¢Â∑•Êï∞Â∞èÊó∂
item.description:
The union representing New York nurses threatened to strike at the city‚Äôs major privately-run hospitals if a new labor contract isn‚Äôt locked in or major progress isn‚Äôt made on Sunday.

The New York State Nurse Association will strike Monday at hospitals including NY Presbyterian, Mount Sinai and Montefiore medical after testy negotiations and an apparent impasse over salaries and benefits, including medical coverage and staffing levels.

Hospital officials said they have prepared strike contingency plans to continue medical appointments and care.

‚ÄúWhile we know a strike can be disruptive, we are prepared for a strike that could last an indefinite amount of time and have taken every step to best support our patients and employees in the event NYSNA forces our nurses to walk away from the bedside for the second time in three years,‚Äù a Mount Sinai spokesperson said.

Mount Sinai said it has hired more than 1,000 nurses across its three hospitals.

‚ÄúWe expect most appointments will proceed as originally scheduled,‚Äù the statement said. ‚ÄúThere has been tremendous coordination across our entire network to manage discharges and ensure that we are prepared for the start of the strike and able to increase our capacity if a potential strike drags on.‚Äù

NYSNA, in an advisory issued Sunday morning, said the strike will begin at 6 a.m. Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital and Mount Sinai Morningside and West facilities ‚Äì and at 7 a.m. at Montefiore, and NewYork-Presbyterian hospitals.

Key sticking points in negotiations, according to NYSNA, include management‚Äôs threats to cut healthcare benefits for frontline nurses, and rolling back safe staffing standards the union secured when its nurses went on strike at two major hospitals three years ago.

The union also claimed hospital management has refused to agree to protections from workplace violence.

It cited an incident last week at Brooklyn Methodist hospital, where a bloodied, blade-wielding patient was shot and killed by cops after he barricaded himself in a room with an elderly patient and a staffer ‚Äî sending the Park Slope medical center into lockdown.

But hospital officials claim the union has submitted outlandish salary demands and rejected proposed safety improvements.

‚ÄúNYSNA leadership‚Äôs reckless and irresponsible demands totaling $3.6 billion, including a nearly 40% wage increase, and taking issue with our reasonable measures like rolling out panic buttons for frontline staff in the Emergency Department, clearly put patients at risk,‚Äù said Joe Solmonese, Montefiore‚Äôs senior vice president for strategic communications.

‚ÄúWe are preparing for what we anticipate could be a multi-week strike, and are resolute in devoting whatever resources are necessary to safe and seamless care for our community.‚Äù

NYSNA claimed its members are not asking for outrageous wage demands.

It said Northwell‚Äôs Plainview, Syosset and Huntington hospital nurses signed tentative agreements on new contracts on Friday that included 5% annual increases over three years and maintained good benefits and bolstered safety standards.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: ÂâçÊñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÂ∑ûÈïøÁêÜÊü•Âæ∑¬∑ÁßëËø™Ôºà Richard Codey ÔºâÂõ†ËÄªËæ±ÁöÑË©πÂßÜÊñØ¬∑È∫¶Ê†ºÈáåÁª¥Ôºà James McGreevey ÔºâÂéª‰∏ñÔºå‰∫´Âπ¥79Â≤Å
item.description:
Former NJ Gov. Richard Codey, the longest-serving legislator in state history who had two brief stints leading the state, has died aged 79 after a brief battle with an unspecified illness.

‚ÄúOur family has lost a beloved husband, father, and grandfather ‚Äî and New Jersey lost a remarkable public servant who touched the lives of all who knew him,‚Äù a statement put out by his family Sunday read in part.

The Democrat served 14 months as governor following the high-profile resignation of James McGreevey in 2004, following his sex and corruption scandal.

Codey also had a brief tenure as acting governor after Gov. Christine Todd Whitman resigned in 2001.

Codey spent 50 years in Trenton, representing the Garden State‚Äôs 26th District in the state assembly between 1974-1982, and the 27th from 1982 until he announced his retirement in 2023.

He announced he wouldn‚Äôt seek re-election just two months after he defeated Sen. Nia Gill in a primary contest for his long-held seat, though he said at the time it was not for health reasons.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sick. I‚Äôm not dying or any of that bulls‚Äìt,‚Äù Codey told the New Jersey Monitor following his announcement. Adding that he was ‚Äúlucky and grateful‚Äù to have his health.

‚ÄúHe lived his life with humility, compassion and a deep sense of responsibility to others,‚Äù the family statement continued.

‚ÄúHe spoke the truth when others wouldn‚Äôt and fought tirelessly for the people of New Jersey during his record-setting 50 years in the Legislature. He made friends as easily with Presidents as he did with strangers in all-night diners.‚Äù
item.author: Chris Nesi

item.title: ÁãÇÈáéÊó∂ÂàªË≠¶ÂØüTaseÂú®Ë¢≠ÂáªÁ•≠ÂùõÂêéÁöÑÊó©Êô®Âº•ÊííÊúüÈó¥Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÊïôÂ†ÇÁñØÁãÇÁöÑÁî∑‰∫∫
item.description:
Wild video shows the moment cops Tased a crazed man inside a New York City church after he stormed the altar and disrupted Mass ‚Äî as horrified parishioners looked on.

The NYPD was called to St. Ann‚Äôs Roman Catholic Church in Staten Island after reports of a disruptive person who was trashing the place,¬†WABC reported.

Shocking video filmed by a parishioner shows the man being Tased by a police officer as the priest ducked out of the way behind the altar during the 7 a.m. Friday Mass.

The two arresting officers punched the man repeatedly in the head as they struggled to get him in handcuffs.

At one stage, the man broke free and started fighting back, sending a display of flowers behind the altar flying.

Before the parishioner started filming, the 28-year-old man snatched, tossed and damaged several religious items on the altar, the church‚Äôs pastor, Rev. Jacob Thumma,¬†told Staten Island Live.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just cleaning up the mess now in the church as we speak,‚Äù Father Thumma told the outlet.

Police had tried speaking to the man before he became violent and belligerant.

Cops were finally able to get the man under control and brought into custody, where charges were pending.

The unidentified individual was taken to the hospital for a medical evaluation.

He is reportedly not a parishioner.

The two arresting officers were treated for minor injuries including a laceration to the head and a knee injury following the brawl.

Minor damage was also sustained to the church altar and the marble floor.
item.author: Anthony Blair

item.title: Â∏ÉÊúóÂÖãÊñØÂ§ßÊ•ºMamdaniÊõæÁªèÂ±ïÁ§∫Êñ∞‰ΩèÊàøÂßîÂëò‰ºöÁöÑÊâçÂçéÊúâ200Ê¨°ËøùËßÑË°å‰∏∫‚ÄîÂú®ÂèóÂà∞ÈùíÁùêÁöÑÈùûËê•Âà©ÁªÑÁªáÂ∞ÜÂÖ∂Â§∑‰∏∫Âπ≥Âú∞‰πãÂêé
item.description:
A¬†Bronx apartment building Mayor Mamdani showcased to highlight the talents of his new housing commissioner, Dina Levy,¬†has racked up nearly 200 unresolved violations, The Post has learned.

The 102-unit building at 1520 Sedgwick Ave. in Morris Heights as of Saturday had a staggering 194 open housing-code violations dating back to 2016 ‚Äî including 88 ‚ÄúClass C‚Äù violations considered ‚Äúimmediately hazardous.‚Äù

They included rat and roach infestation; broken doors and refrigerators; and mold, records show.

Mamdani visited the affordable-housing complex best known for being the birthplace of hip-hop on Jan. 4 to introduce Levy, 54, a longtime tenants‚Äô rights advocate and former state housing honcho, as his new Housing Preservation and Development commissioner.

He gushed how Levy ‚Äî who grew up the silver-spooned daughter of two high-powered DC lawyers ‚Äì has non-profit experience in building and overseeing affordable housing, a perfect fit for his leftist housing agenda that seeks to replace private landlords wherever possible.

Levy, who will make $277,605 a year as HPD commissioner, helped facilitate a 2011 deal for nonprofit Workforce Housing Advisors to buy and rehab the Sedgwick Avenue complex from private landlords.

Levy did this with help from a $5.6 million HPD loan she and her own nonprofit, the Urban Homesteading Assistance Board, brokered to stabilize the building‚Äôs finances and maintain its ‚Äúaffordable‚Äù rental status, recalled Mamdani.

‚ÄúDina will no longer be petitioning HPD from the outside,‚Äù the mayor touted. ‚ÄúShe will now be leading it from the inside, delivering the kind of change that can transform lives.‚Äù

However, the 59-year-old building isn‚Äôt the success story Mamdani and Levy claim it to be, The Post found.

It has more than double the dangerous ‚ÄúClass C‚Äù violations racked up at 85 Clarkson Ave., a dilapidated, privately owned 71-unit complex in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, Mamdani showcased three days earlier as a poster child for everything he believes is wrong with the city‚Äôs publicly-subsidized housing stock.

Tenants told The Post conditions were better under the old, private landlord.

‚ÄúI have been here over 20 years, and I preferred it when it was under private management because they used to screen people in and out of the building,‚Äù said Mordistine Alexander, among the dozens of tenants at 1520 Sedgwick whose homes have open HPD violations.

Alexander, 49, who has rented her three-bedroom apartment since 1999, said the unit routinely lacks heat and hot water, its bathroom and kitchen facades are crumbling and windows need to be replaced

She said she‚Äôs been without a kitchen light for months ‚Äî despite asking for fluorescent light bulbs to be replaced since October.

And she said she had to take care of fixing a major rodent problem in the unit herself because she ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt wait any longer‚Äù for Workforce Housing Group to respond.

‚ÄúSince [the nonprofit] took over, the building has deteriorated. They lack porters. No one is maintaining it, and the complaints fall on deaf ears ‚Äì especially if you complain a lot,‚Äù said Alexander, adding she wishes Levy never won her fight to turn the building over to the nonprofit.

Yet Mamdani wants more complexes like the Sedgewick Avenue building. He supports Stalinesque legislation¬†designed to control how private property is sold¬†so that more nonprofits can oversee rent-stabilized apartments.

‚ÄúYou have to laugh at the hypocrisy,‚Äù said Councilwoman Joann Ariola (R-Queens). ‚ÄúThese nonprofits are proving themselves to be little more than taxpayer-funded slumlords, and this blatant double-standard is all part of the administration‚Äôs planned attack on private ownership in New York City.‚Äù

Like Cea Weaver, the much-maligned lefty boss of Mamdani‚Äôs newly created Mayor‚Äôs Office to Protect Tenants, HPD Commissioner Levy grew up in privilege.

She is the twin daughter of lawyer Ed Levy and his late civil-rights attorney wife Mary, who owned multiple properties, including a townhouse in historic Georgetown they sold in 2023 that is currently worth $1.4 million. She has said she is a native of affluent Maplewood, NJ.

Levy, a Delaware University graduate, has been a rebel-rousing, radical tenant advocate for decades, even spending time in the slammer as a young organizer.

‚ÄúIt was cool,‚Äù Levy once told Crain‚Äôs New York Business of her 1997 Dallas arrest for criminal trespassing at a run-down affordable-housing complex. ‚ÄúI got really hooked.‚Äù

Levy boasted in the 2011 interview that her ‚Äúrough, caustic style‚Äù irks landlords.

The Sedgwick Avenue site has more open HPD violations than roughly three-quarters of the privately owned, rent-stabilized buildings in NYC ‚Äî but Mamdani is ‚Äútoo focused‚Äù on pushing the abolition of private property, said Kenny Burgos, a former Bronx assemblyman who heads the New York Apartment Association that represents landlords of rent-stabilized units.

Nonprofit-managed housing ‚Äúconsistently run¬†higher violation counts despite having government-backed loans and [being eligible to avoid] paying property taxes, so they should have a lot more freed-up cash to make these buildings run efficiently, and yet are unable to do so ‚Äî even with good intentions and no goal of profit,‚Äù added Burgos.

Workforce Housing Group did not return messages, but the HPD defended Levy‚Äôs involvement in the sale of the Sedgwick Avenue building to the nonprofit group.

‚ÄúWhen the building was at risk of being purchased by a predatory buyer, Dina Levy organized alongside the tenants and kept the building affordable,‚Äù said agency spokesman Matt Rauschenbach.

‚ÄúAnd now the building is undergoing an $8 million preservation renovation to improve conditions and make sure it is a safe, affordable place for the tenants who live there to call home.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Rich Calder

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥È¢àÈÉ®Ë¢´Âà∫‰º§ÔºåÂú®‰∫âÊâßÂêéË¢´ÊùÄÔºö ‚Äú‰ªÄ‰πàÁΩ™ÊÅ∂‚Äù
item.description:
A Queens teen ran for his life after an argument ‚Äî but couldn‚Äôt escape a bloody end on a Woodhaven sidewalk, authorities said.

Josue Argudo was in a dispute with two others around 3:45 p.m. Friday when he tried to flee, authorities said.

But the assailants caught up with the 17-year-old, with one punching him and the other stabbing him in the neck at the corner of Jamaica Avenue and 76th Street, cops said.

EMS rushed the victim to Jamaica Hospital in critical condition, but he was later pronounced dead. There have been no arrests, cops said.

Neighbor Patricia Ammirati was in her kitchen and heard teens arguing outside before the stabbing.

‚ÄúThe back door was open,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI look out, and I see the boy with the light gray [sweatshirt] sitting down. And then he slumped over. It was so fast.‚Äù

Her neighbors gave the teen CPR to no avail, she said.

Her surveillance camera caught what appeared to be the victim and another teen walking down the street.

The two walk next to each other before the suspect appears to jab the victim in the neck, video viewed by The Post shows.¬†

‚ÄúI thought he was punching him but the guy in black must have had the knife wrapped up around his hand,‚Äù she said.¬†

‚ÄúThe kid sat down, and then he slumped over,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhat a sin.‚Äù

An investigation is ongoing, said cops, who are hunting for the teens and released photos of both suspects.

She said the teen and another boy casually walked away after the assault.

‚ÄúThey just walked away like nothing happened,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúLike nothing. They don‚Äôt care. They have no regards.‚Äù¬†

She regrets that she wasn‚Äôt outside to try to stop the violence.

‚ÄúIf I were outside 10 minutes more, maybe I could have stopped it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd say, ‚ÄòThis ain‚Äôt happening on my corner!‚Äô I wish I could have saved the boy‚Äôs life.‚Äù
item.author: Jennifer Bain, Tina Moore

item.title: Â†ïËêΩÁò´Áó™ÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏Ç‰æ¶Êé¢Âè≤ËíÇÊñá¬∑È∫¶ÂÖãÂîêÁ∫≥Ôºà Steven McDonald ÔºâÂú®ÈÄù‰∏ñ9Âë®Âπ¥
item.description:
Family and friends gathered to remember fallen NYPD Detective Steven McDonald on the 9th anniversary of his death at St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral in Manhattan on Saturday.¬†

McDonald was a 29-year-old patrolman when he was shot three times on July 12, 1986, by a 15-year-old boy while he was questioning the teen about bicycle thefts in Central Park.¬†

One of the bullets shattered his spine, paralyzing him from the neck down and leaving him in need of a ventilator for the rest of his life. He died 31 years later on Jan. 10, 2017, from respiratory complications at age 59.

‚ÄúMy father was a tremendous human being,‚Äù his son, NYPD Captain Conor McDonald, told The Post. ‚ÄúHe faced evil and darkness and he overcame it through the power of prayer and love.‚Äù

McDonald was joined in the gathering in the iconic cathedral on Fifth Avenue by his wife and two children, his mother, Patricia McDonald, who was three months pregnant with him when his dad was shot, and dozens of NYPD members and officials, including Police Commissioner Jessica Tisch.

‚ÄúAfter the shooting he was given three to five years to live,‚Äù McDonald recalled. ‚ÄúThe doctors didn‚Äôt think he was going to be able to survive the injuries for that long. He believed the grace of God gave him the power to overcome his injuries.‚Äù

The teen who shot McDonald served nine years in prison. He was killed in a motorcycle crash four days after his release on parole.

‚ÄúMy dad was just remarkable,‚Äù the son recalled. ‚ÄúHe could go from Chinatown to 125th Street to Middle Village and he could connect with anybody. He made it his mission to bridge the gap between all different communities. He just wanted to make NYC and the world a better place.‚Äù

One of the speakers at the event echoed that sentiment.

‚ÄúHe gave us hope,‚Äù Police Benevolent Association President Patrick Hendry told the attendees. ‚ÄúHe inspired us to always be grateful for what we have, to give back to others. He was truly one of a kind.‚Äù

Detectives Endowment Association President Scott Munro told the congregants how McDonald would visit precinct roll calls around the city in his wheelchair, ‚Äúspeaking directly with cops.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhether you were a rookie or a seasoned detective he met you where you were ‚Äì with humility, sincerity and respect,‚Äù Munro said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why his words stayed with you long after the conversation ended.‚Äù
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁà∂‰∫≤ÁöÑÂ•≥ÂÑøË¢´ËÅå‰∏öÁΩ™ÁäØÈöèÊú∫Âà∫Ê≠ªÔºåÂ§ßÂ£∞ËØ¥Ôºö ‚ÄúÊàëÂè™ÊòØ‰∏çÂÅúÂú∞Âì≠Ê≥£‚Äù
item.description:
The heart-broken daughter of a security guard fatally stabbed by a deranged career-criminal in the Bronx wept as she recalled her beloved father to The Post, saying, ‚ÄúHe was the best dad.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just keep crying,‚Äù Nana Yaa Fosua Ennin, whose dad George was killed as he walked to work this week in Mott Haven, said Saturday.

Father-of-two George Ennin, 53, was jumped and stabbed multiple times.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not fair to me,‚Äù the teary 18-year-old said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt even get to touch him. I didn‚Äôt get to feel him and I just keep crying and I don‚Äôt even know what to do. I just wish I could at least hug him physically.‚Äù

She last spoke to her dad two days before he died, while she was away visiting her aunt in Maryland.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so sad to see him gone too soon,‚Äù¬† said the teen who recently graduated from high school and has a 17-year-old sister. ‚ÄúIt was not his time to go at all and someone just cut his life short.‚Äù

Sean Jones, a 38-year-old repeat offender with a history of violent assaults in Manhattan and the Bronx, was charged with murder, manslaughter and weapons possession in the unprovoked attack, police said.¬†

Jones pleaded not guilty Friday night and is being held without bail.

The victim was the eldest of six children. One sister, Lucy Adusei, 42, said she was frustrated by New York‚Äôs lax criminal justice system and amazed that someone with Jones‚Äô criminal history could be on the street.

‚ÄúI think New York law is too lenient with people like this,‚Äù the psychiatric nurse said.¬†

‚ÄúSometimes people do it knowingly, they know exactly what they‚Äôre doing but they pretend that once the issue happens it‚Äôs a psychiatric issue,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a psychiatric nurse. Sometimes they do these things on purpose.‚Äù

Her brother didn‚Äôt deserve to die and she wants justice, she told The Post.

‚ÄúIf it was up to me the death sentence would be good for him,‚Äù she said of the suspect, noting New York doesn‚Äôt have the death penalty.

‚ÄúThe ironic¬†part of it is that even if it‚Äôs life imprisonment, you know what? I‚Äôm still gonna work and my taxes are going to feed him,‚Äù she said.

She‚Äôll never be able to unsee the video of the fatal confrontation.

‚ÄúThe video is registered in my mind,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI cannot erase the video, it‚Äôs stuck in my memory. It will be there forever.‚Äù

Another sister, Regina Adusei Brenfaah, 46, had the unfortunate task of telling her mother and sisters about George‚Äôs death.

‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòNo, it‚Äôs not George, it‚Äôs not George, he had no enemies!‚Äô‚Äù she recalled.

Sister Anatasia Brentuo, 52, remembered getting that call.

‚Äú‚ÄòOur brother is gone, he‚Äôs gone, somebody stabbed him, he‚Äôs dead!‚Äô‚Äù she recalled her sister yelling into the phone. ‚ÄúI said, ‚ÄòNo, no, it‚Äôs not true.'‚Äù¬†¬†

‚ÄúThis was hard to believe,‚Äù Brentuo said. ‚ÄúMy mother called me, she said, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm dying here, I‚Äôm dying here.‚Äô‚Äù

Brentuo said her brother was an ‚Äúinnocent soul‚Äù and a Christian who came to the US from Ghana to¬†have a better life.

‚ÄúHe was a good father, a single father, a single parent, raising his two girls,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe loved them very much.‚Äù
item.author: Georgett Roberts, Tina Moore
